LECTURE ON ILLUMINANTS

TO DISCUSS INFANT MORTALITY

Mr. Lansingh Speaks to a Large Audience in McCoy Hall—Aaparatus
Set up for Inspection.

Important Convention to be held in
McCoy Hall—Will mark a New
Era in Preventive Medicine.

Last Monday evening a large
crowd attended the popular lecture
given by Mr. Van Rensselaer Lansingh on "Illuminating Engineering." The lecturer, who was introduced by President Remsen, gave
a short talk entirely free of technicalities, illustrating his remarks
by a series.:, of well-arranged -experiments. .
Mr. Lansing,th first pointed out
the difference in efficiency of the
various kinds of gas lamps. He
showed that the ordinary fish-tail
burner is only One-fifth as efficient
as the Welsbach burner. The inverted mantle gives about the same
candle power per cubic foot of gas
burned as the upright Welsbach ;
the advantage of the inverted burner lies in its greater convenience
from the point of view of shading
the light.
There is a great difference
between the different forms of incandescent electric lights. The
ordinary carbon filament lamp uses
from 3 to 37
2 watts of current
per Candle power. The lamp in
which -the.carbon filament has been
treated by a special process uses
21
/
2 watts per candle power. The
tantalum lamp uses 2 watts and
th tungsten---"Mazda"—lamp only
1;4 watts per candle power. The
' last-named lamp is thus three times
as efficient as the ordinary carbon
filament lamp.
In addition a number of lamps
used to light large buildings and
streets were shown. The most
interesting of these were the
mercury-vapor lamp and the flaming-arc. The mercury-vapor lamp,
because of its peculiar effect upon
colors, is used only for industrial
lighting where color is of no consequence. The difference between
the flaming arc and the ordinary arc
lamp is that the carbon poles of the
flaming arc are steeped in the solution of some salt which colors the
flame. It has been found that a
:pinkish-yellow light is most efficient.
The effect of the various kinds
of light on color was interesting.
. Perhaps the most striking case was
that of the mercury-vapor lamp.
,A red object introduced into the
light of this lamp appeared a deep
purple, almost a black. This is due
to the fact that re41 rays are almost
entirely absent from this light.
After the close of the lecture
the audience was invited to step
up to the platform and examine
the experimental apparatus. In the

Hopkins alumni are actively interested in the annual meeting of the
American Association for Study
and Prevention of Infapt Mortality
which is to be held in McCoy Hall,
November 9th to II th. Dr. J. H.
Mason Knox, Jr., Hopkins Medical
School, 1898, now of the Medical
School Faculty, is president of the
Association, and among the directors are Dr. Wm. H. Welch;
Dr. Harry T. Marshall, '98, now
professor of pathology in the University of Virginia; Dr. Clemens
von Pirquet, of the Medical School
Faculty;. Dr. H. Merriman Steele,
of New Haven Medical School,
Iopkins 1902, now of the department of pediatrics at Yale; and
Dr. R. A. Urquhart of the Medical
School Faculty. Dr. J. Whitridge
\Villiams, president of the Alumni
Association, is scheduled to read a
paper at one of the sessions.
The subject for the opening session, which will take place Wednesday evening, November 9th, will
be "The Duty of a Nation to Its
Potential Citizens." The speakers
\\'ill include M. Jusserand, the
French ambassador to this country;
Dr. Wm. H. Welch; Prof. Irving
Fisher, of Yale; and Dr. Abraham
Jacobi, of New York. Two general sessions will be held on Thursday, one in the morning, and the
other at night. At the former, the
prevention of infant mortality by
philanthropic measures will be discussed and the chairman will be Dr.
Hastings H. Hart, of New York,
director of the Deparment of Child
Helping of the Russell Sage
Foundation. The night session will
be on Municipal, State, and Federal
Prevention, and will be under the
chairmanship of Dr. Wm. H.
Welch. Dr. L. Emmett Holt, of
New York, professor of the diseases of children at Columbia University, will preside at the session
on "Medical Prevention" Friday
morning; and Dr. Helen C. Putnam, of Providence, will be chairman of the session on "Educational
Prevention," which will be held on
Friday afternoon.
In connection with the meeting,
an exhibition will be held which
will continue for one week. Dr.
Marshall L. Price, secretary of the
Maryland Department of Health, is
chairman of the committee on the
exhibition, which is being arranged
by Dr. J. W. Shereschewsky the,
officer of the United States Public
Health and Marine Hospital Ser(Continued on page 3, col. 4.)

THE NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 31, 1910
,

Medical School.

The Federated Charities will hold
a meeting for medical students in
the medical amphitheatre on Friday afternoon, October 26, at five
o'clock P. M. The meeting will be
addressed by Dr. Hurd, Dr. Emerson, and Mr. Magruder.
In accordance with a custom inaugurated last year, the entering
students have all been requested to
submit to a physical examination
by some physician connected with
the Hopkins Hospital. There are
ninety students in the class. For
this examination, nine have been
assigned to each of the following
men :
Drs. R. T. Brown, J. A. Chatard,
Thomas McCrae, T. B. Tuscher,
J. A. Leutscher, T. R. Bogg, G. L.
Taneyhill, Jr., L. Hamman, F. R.
Smith, and S. Wolman.
The first meeting for this year
of the Christian Organization was
held in the Garrett Room, on Monday, October 24, at 7.15 o'clock.
Regular meetings will be held every
two weeks in the same place on
Monday evenings. The organization occupies somewhat the place
held by the Y. M. C. A. in other
schools.
Dr. Kelly Receives.

In spite of a heavy rain there
were about seventy-five men, mostly students at the Medical Schools
of the city at the reception given by
Dr. Kelly at his residence on Fri4lay evening, October 21.
Dr. Kelly was unavoidably detained and about half-past eight
Mr. Morris, general secretary of
the Central Y. M. C. A. arose and
introduced the speaker of the evening, Mr. Clayton S. Cooper, of
New York, secretary of the International Students Y. M. C. A.
Mr. Cooper gave a powerful and
intensely interesting talk. He referred to the large number of students interested in the present Bible
study movement, and gave some
comparative figures in regard to the
number of Bibles sold.
Dr. Cullen, of the Medical Faculty, and Mr. John Holmes, of the
University Y. M. C. A. also made
short talks. Mr. Hering and Mr.
Wu also said a few words.
As the last speaker finished Dr.
Kelly arrived, and, excusing his
late appearance, he invited the men
to his dining room for refreshments which was the last number
on the evening's program.

ALUMNI NOTES
Sylvester K. Loy, Ph.D., 'io, is
acting professor of chemistry at
Symons College, Boston.
Thomas A. Lewis, Ph.D. 'io, has
been appointed professor of philosophy at Richmond College, Va.
Arthur H. Estabrook, Ph.D., '10,
will spend the winter in research
work at Cold Spring Harbor, Long
Island.
J. F. Daniel, Ph.D.,'09, has been
appointed instructor in comparative
anatomy at the University of California.
Charles B. Wilson, Ph.D., '10,
has been appointed professor of
biology at the State Normal School,
Westfield, Mass.
T. S. Will, '10, who is a firstyear student at the Virginia Theological Seminary, near Washington,
has a congregation at Fells Point,
near Baltimore.
J. R. B. Branch, A. B. '04, M.
D. '08, is Superintendent of the
Macon (Ga.) Hospital.
Geologists in Training.

Ideal weather favored the class
in Geology I on their second excursion on Wednesday last. The region selected for the afternoon's
study was the Jones Falls valley.
The first stop was made at the
gorge near the Mount Vernon Cotton Duck Mills. Here the class,
numbering already thirty, was augmented for the time being by four
passers-by, who appeared to be
seriously interested in Dr. Swartz's
explanation of the physiographic
features.
From there the route lay to the
Bare Hills. At this place work
was temporarily interfered with by
an officious track-walker, who insisted that the class should not
stand on the tracks or near them
while studying the rock formations
along the railroad.
The original plan was that the
class should go as far as the Green
Spring Valley, but the time was too
short, and after a short stay at the
Bare Hills, the homeward journey
was begun.

"Dr. A. H. Tuttle, professor of
biology at the university, took a
trip to the Johns Hopkins University in order to perform some reseach work there."—U. of Va.
"College Topics."
R. M. Overbeck, '09, is at present teaching at Marston's University School as successor to John M.
Super, '05, who died recently.
The University of North Carolina celebrated the one hundred and
seventeenth anniversary of its
founding on October twelfth.
As mentioned in another column
the response to the call for the
musical clubs has been very encouraging. In this connection it
is interesting to see that the University of Virginia, with nearly one
thousand studens, has musical clubs
with a membership of fifty-five,:
not so good a showing in proportion to the student body.
Mr. John D. Rockefeller recently
offered Western Reserve University the sum of $250,0oo provided
that a further amount of $750,000
be subscribed. Mr. Hanna, of
Cleveland, has already subscribed
$250,000 of the additional sum required.
On September 16 the erection
of a new zoological laboratory for
the University of Pennsylvania was
begun. It will be the largest
zoological building yet constructed
and is to cost from $25o,00o to
$3oo,000.
Thirty-seven universities abroad
were founded before 1420. A few
of them whose names are familiar
are: Oxford, England, founded
1200; University of Paris, 1200;
University of Parma, 1222; University of Salamanca, Spain, 1243;
Cambridge University, 1257; University of Vienna, 1365; Heidelberg
University, 1386; St. Andrew's
University, Scotland, 1411.
Dr. Lewellys F. Barker, professor of medicine in. the Hopkins
medical school, has returned from
a motor trip through the Valley
of Virginia, during which he was
the guest of Mr. Matthew Page
Andrews.

vice at this port, who has been
detailed by Surgeon-General Wyman, of that service, to act as medical officer in charge of the exhibit.
The exhibition is the first of
equal scope to be held in this country, and it is expected that it will
mark as great an era in preventive
work along this particular line, as
the tuberculosis exhibit held at
McCoy Hall in 1904. The name of
the University will always be linked
with the tuberculosis exhibition,
which was not only the forerunner
of the great exhibitions since held
in this country, but which gave
the powerful impulse to the crusade, now national in scope, against
tuberculosis. It is predicted that
the exhibition being assembled for
the meeting next week, will mark
the beginning of an equally great
popular crusade in the interest of
better conditions for the nation's
"potential citizens."
Membership in the American
Association for Study and Prevention of Infant Mortality is about
equally divided between laymen and
physicians. The meetings and the
exhibition will be all open to the
public.
Track Coach Wanted.

At a meeting of the Advisory
Board of the Johns Hopkins University Track Team, held at the
Hopkins Club, on Wednesday night,
the prospects for the season of
1910-11 were discussed, and it was
agreed that the outlook is particularly bright. Outdoor meets are
likely to be held with University
of Pennsylvania, Naval Academy,
Haverford, and University of Virginia.
The most important matter under
discussion, however, was the selection of a coach for the team. Being unable to reach a final decision,
it was determined to issue a call for
candidates for this position through
the columns of THE NEWS-LETTER.
Candidates must be equipped with
a thorough knowledge of all the
branches of track athletics, and also
with a systematic method of coaching. It is likewise all important
that the candidate should be willing
to devote the full amount of time
required to turn out a winning
team.
Applications should be mailed
immediately to H. B. Hering,
manager, Box 267, Johns Hopkins
University.

LECTURE ON ILLUMINANTS

TO DISCUSS INFANT MORTALITY

Mr. Lansingh Speaks to a Large Audience in McCoy Hall—Aaparatus
Set up for Inspection.

Important Convention to be held in
McCoy Hall—Will mark a New
Era in Preventive Medicine.

Last Monday evening a large
crowd attended the popular lecture
given by Mr. Van Rensselaer Lansingh on "Illuminating Engineering." The lecturer, who was introduced by President Remsen, gave
a short talk entirely free of technicalities, illustrating his remarks
by a series.:, of well-arranged -experiments. .
Mr. Lansing,th first pointed out
the difference in efficiency of the
various kinds of gas lamps. He
showed that the ordinary fish-tail
burner is only One-fifth as efficient
as the Welsbach burner. The inverted mantle gives about the same
candle power per cubic foot of gas
burned as the upright Welsbach ;
the advantage of the inverted burner lies in its greater convenience
from the point of view of shading
the light.
There is a great difference
between the different forms of incandescent electric lights. The
ordinary carbon filament lamp uses
from 3 to 37
2 watts of current
per Candle power. The lamp in
which -the.carbon filament has been
treated by a special process uses
21
/
2 watts per candle power. The
tantalum lamp uses 2 watts and
th tungsten---"Mazda"—lamp only
1;4 watts per candle power. The
' last-named lamp is thus three times
as efficient as the ordinary carbon
filament lamp.
In addition a number of lamps
used to light large buildings and
streets were shown. The most
interesting of these were the
mercury-vapor lamp and the flaming-arc. The mercury-vapor lamp,
because of its peculiar effect upon
colors, is used only for industrial
lighting where color is of no consequence. The difference between
the flaming arc and the ordinary arc
lamp is that the carbon poles of the
flaming arc are steeped in the solution of some salt which colors the
flame. It has been found that a
:pinkish-yellow light is most efficient.
The effect of the various kinds
of light on color was interesting.
. Perhaps the most striking case was
that of the mercury-vapor lamp.

Hopkins alumni are actively interested in the annual meeting of the
American Association for Study
and Prevention of Infapt Mortality
which is to be held in McCoy Hall,
November 9th to II th. Dr. J. H.
Mason Knox, Jr., Hopkins Medical
School, 1898, now of the Medical
School Faculty, is president of the
Association, and among the directors are Dr. Wm. H. Welch;
Dr. Harry T. Marshall, '98, now
professor of pathology in the University of Virginia; Dr. Clemens
von Pirquet, of the Medical School
Faculty;. Dr. H. Merriman Steele,
of New Haven Medical School,
Iopkins 1902, now of the department of pediatrics at Yale; and
Dr. R. A. Urquhart of the Medical
School Faculty. Dr. J. Whitridge
\Villiams, president of the Alumni
Association, is scheduled to read a
paper at one of the sessions.
The subject for the opening session, which will take place Wednesday evening, November 9th, will
be "The Duty of a Nation to Its
Potential Citizens." The speakers
\\'ill include M. Jusserand, the
French ambassador to this country;
Dr. Wm. H. Welch; Prof. Irving
Fisher, of Yale; and Dr. Abraham
Jacobi, of New York. Two general sessions will be held on Thursday, one in the morning, and the
other at night. At the former, the
prevention of infant mortality by
philanthropic measures will be discussed and the chairman will be Dr.
Hastings H. Hart, of New York,
director of the Deparment of Child
Helping of the Russell Sage
Foundation. The night session will
be on Municipal, State, and Federal
Prevention, and will be under the
chairmanship of Dr. Wm. H.
Welch. Dr. L. Emmett Holt, of
New York, professor of the diseases of children at Columbia University, will preside at the session
on "Medical Prevention" Friday
morning; and Dr. Helen C. Putnam, of Providence, will be chairman of the session on "Educational
Prevention," which will be held on
Friday afternoon.
In connection with the meeting,
an exhibition will be held which
will continue for one week. Dr.
Marshall L. Price, secretary of the
Maryland Department of Health, is
chairman of the committee on the
exhibition, which is being arranged

Medical School.

The Federated Charities will hold
a meeting for medical students in
the medical amphitheatre on Friday afternoon, October 26, at five
o'clock P. M. The meeting will be
addressed by Dr. Hurd, Dr. Emerson, and Mr. Magruder.
In accordance with a custom inaugurated last year, the entering
students have all been requested to
submit to a physical examination
by some physician connected with
the Hopkins Hospital. There are
ninety students in the class. For
this examination, nine have been
assigned to each of the following
men :
Drs. R. T. Brown, J. A. Chatard,
Thomas McCrae, T. B. Tuscher,
J. A. Leutscher, T. R. Bogg, G. L.
Taneyhill, Jr., L. Hamman, F. R.
Smith, and S. Wolman.
The first meeting for this year
of the Christian Organization was
held in the Garrett Room, on Monday, October 24, at 7.15 o'clock.
Regular meetings will be held every
two weeks in the same place on
Monday evenings. The organization occupies somewhat the place
held by the Y. M. C. A. in other
schools.
Dr. Kelly Receives.

In spite of a heavy rain there
were about seventy-five men, mostly students at the Medical Schools
of the city at the reception given by
Dr. Kelly at his residence on Fri4lay evening, October 21.
Dr. Kelly was unavoidably detained and about half-past eight
Mr. Morris, general secretary of
the Central Y. M. C. A. arose and
introduced the speaker of the evening, Mr. Clayton S. Cooper, of
New York, secretary of the International Students Y. M. C. A.
Mr. Cooper gave a powerful and
intensely interesting talk. He referred to the large number of students interested in the present Bible
study movement, and gave some
comparative figures in regard to the
number of Bibles sold.
Dr. Cullen, of the Medical Faculty, and Mr. John Holmes, of the
University Y. M. C. A. also made
short talks. Mr. Hering and Mr.
Wu also said a few words.
As the last speaker finished Dr.
Kelly arrived, and, excusing his
late appearance, he invited the men
to his dining room for refreshments which was the last number
on the evening's program.

ALUMNI NOTES
Sylvester K. Loy, Ph.D., 'io, is
acting professor of chemistry at
Symons College, Boston.
Thomas A. Lewis, Ph.D. 'io, has
been appointed professor of philosophy at Richmond College, Va.
Arthur H. Estabrook, Ph.D., '10,
will spend the winter in research
work at Cold Spring Harbor, Long
Island.
J. F. Daniel, Ph.D.,'09, has been
appointed instructor in comparative
anatomy at the University of California.
Charles B. Wilson, Ph.D., '10,
has been appointed professor of
biology at the State Normal School,
Westfield, Mass.
T. S. Will, '10, who is a firstyear student at the Virginia Theological Seminary, near Washington,
has a congregation at Fells Point,
near Baltimore.
J. R. B. Branch, A. B. '04, M.
D. '08, is Superintendent of the
Macon (Ga.) Hospital.
Geologists in Training.

Ideal weather favored the class
in Geology I on their second excursion on Wednesday last. The region selected for the afternoon's
study was the Jones Falls valley.
The first stop was made at the
gorge near the Mount Vernon Cotton Duck Mills. Here the class,
numbering already thirty, was augmented for the time being by four
passers-by, who appeared to be
seriously interested in Dr. Swartz's
explanation of the physiographic
features.
From there the route lay to the
Bare Hills. At this place work
was temporarily interfered with by
an officious track-walker, who insisted that the class should not
stand on the tracks or near them
while studying the rock formations
along the railroad.
The original plan was that the
class should go as far as the Green
Spring Valley, but the time was too
short, and after a short stay at the
Bare Hills, the homeward journey
was begun.

biology at the university, took a

"College Topics."
R. M. Overbeck, '09, is at present teaching at Marston's University School as successor to John M.
Super, '05, who died recently.
The University of North Carolina celebrated the one hundred and
seventeenth anniversary of its
founding on October twelfth.
As mentioned in another column
the response to the call for the
musical clubs has been very encouraging. In this connection it
is interesting to see that the University of Virginia, with nearly one
thousand studens, has musical clubs
with a membership of fifty-five,:
not so good a showing in proportion to the student body.
Mr. John D. Rockefeller recently
offered Western Reserve University the sum of $250,0oo provided
that a further amount of $750,000
be subscribed. Mr. Hanna, of
Cleveland, has already subscribed
$250,000 of the additional sum required.
On September 16 the erection
of a new zoological laboratory for
the University of Pennsylvania was
begun. It will be the largest
zoological building yet constructed
and is to cost from $25o,00o to
$3oo,000.
Thirty-seven universities abroad
were founded before 1420. A few
of them whose names are familiar
are: Oxford, England, founded
1200; University of Paris, 1200;
University of Parma, 1222; University of Salamanca, Spain, 1243;
Cambridge University, 1257; University of Vienna, 1365; Heidelberg
University, 1386; St. Andrew's
University, Scotland, 1411.
Dr. Lewellys F. Barker, professor of medicine in. the Hopkins
medical school, has returned from
a motor trip through the Valley
of Virginia, during which he was
the guest of Mr. Matthew Page
Andrews.

vice at this port, who has been
detailed by Surgeon-General Wyman, of that service, to act as medical officer in charge of the exhibit.
The exhibition is the first of
equal scope to be held in this country, and it is expected that it will
mark as great an era in preventive
work along this particular line, as
the tuberculosis exhibit held at
McCoy Hall in 1904. The name of
the University will always be linked
with the tuberculosis exhibition,
which was not only the forerunner
of the great exhibitions since held
in this country, but which gave
the powerful impulse to the crusade, now national in scope, against
tuberculosis. It is predicted that
the exhibition being assembled for
the meeting next week, will mark
the beginning of an equally great
popular crusade in the interest of
better conditions for the nation's
"potential citizens."
Membership in the American
Association for Study and Prevention of Infant Mortality is about
equally divided between laymen and
physicians. The meetings and the
exhibition will be all open to the
public.
Track Coach Wanted.

At a meeting of the Advisory
Board of the Johns Hopkins University Track Team, held at the
Hopkins Club, on Wednesday night,
the prospects for the season of
1910-11 were discussed, and it was
agreed that the outlook is particularly bright. Outdoor meets are
likely to be held with University
of Pennsylvania, Naval Academy,
Haverford, and University of Virginia.
The most important matter under
discussion, however, was the selection of a coach for the team. Being unable to reach a final decision,
it was determined to issue a call for
candidates for this position through
the columns of THE NEWS-LETTER.
Candidates must be equipped with
a thorough knowledge of all the
branches of track athletics, and also
with a systematic method of coaching. It is likewise all important
that the candidate should be willing
to devote the full amount of time
required to turn out a winning
team.
Applications should be mailed
immediately to H. B. Hering,
manager, Box 267, Johns Hopkins
University.
